<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>Apollo 11 astronaut Michael Collins, the third crew member on the first mission to the moon, died this week at 90. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Unlike Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin, Collins never walked on the lunar surface, and instead piloted the command module around the moon while Armstrong and Aldrin snagged the headlines. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">As Collins passed the dark side of the moon, his communications with Earth were completely severed, making him possibly the most isolated person ever to live. “If a count were taken, the score would be three billion plus two over on the other side of the moon, and one plus God only knows what on this side,” he wrote.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But Collins, like many of us this past year, somehow managed to find comfort in that loneliness. “I had this beautiful little domain,” he said. “I was the emperor, the captain of it, and it was quite commodious. I had warm coffee, even.” Sometimes it’s the little things.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal</p>
</div>

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers With... Andrew Ross Sorkin
</h1>
<img alt="Andrew Ross Sorkin" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80OTE0L2FuZHJld19yb3NzX3Nvcmtpbi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Thos Robinson/Getty Images for New York Times</em>
</small>
</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Journalist Andrew Ross Sorkin co-anchors CNBC's <em>Squawk Box</em>, founded the OG business newsletter DealBook, interviewed Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev the night of the GameStop fiasco, wrote <em>Too Big to Fail, </em>co-created <em>Billions</em>, says "<a href="https://twitter.com/andrewrsorkin/status/1384148090005848072?s=20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">good morning</a>" to everyone on his morning runs through Central Park...is there anything the man can't do? </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We asked him some icebreaker questions to find out. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What activities, realizations, or new ways of doing things will you (try to) keep from this past year?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It's probably a cliche, but the pandemic created a lot of clarity for me about better balancing work with family. I work 80+ hours a week and I've always done it because I love it. (I don't feel like I've worked a day in my life, for real.) But being at an office and traveling all the time is different than working next to my sons or daughter at home. So I'm going to try to figure out how to do a lot more of my work with my family within reach and to be more strategic about travel, work dinners, etc. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>You can only do one: writing for the New York Times, TV anchoring, or producing (co-creating </strong><strong><em>Billions</em></strong><strong> for Showtime, developing a GameStop film for HBO).</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Don't hate me for this answer: I genuinely love all three. It is kinda like asking which of my three children I would be willing to give up! None of them!</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Most intimidating exec to interview?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The first time I did a long-form interview with Bill Gates, maybe a decade ago, I was practically sweating. It isn't that he is intimidating as a person; it is that he is so smart and deep on so many different topics. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What's the best part about waking up at 4:30am? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Honestly? That hour is tough. But I do jump out of bed excited about the opportunity to have breakfast—on television, no less—with some of the biggest newsmakers in the world, often in the middle of the most interesting moments of their lives. And there is very little traffic then. :)</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>If you could devote a year to researching someone's biography, who would your subject be?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Living or dead? Satoshi Nakamoto. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What is the dumbest thing you made your parents buy for you as a kid?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I was a baseball and basketball card junkie and a wannabe entrepreneur. I convinced my father, based on my track record of making money trading cards, to invest in a case of Fleer Ultra baseball cards. I told him we'd double our money. Of course, the cards are now worthless—less than worthless. We still have the cards if anyone wants to buy them.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What would you write on a gigantic billboard?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">"Breathe. Things are never as good or as bad as they seem."</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse" width="100%">
<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px">

<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
How Do I Overcome Imposter Syndrome?
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/30/make-work-overcome-imposter-syndrome" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make It Work logo" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Each week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reader-submitted questions</a> about work in 2021. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Q: "Hi, Kate. I'm 24 years old and a few years into my career as a software engineer. I've suffered from impostor syndrome since I was a freshman in college. Any advice on overcoming this?"—Justin in Colorado </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>A: </strong>Imposter syndrome makes things seem too good to be true, huh? Been there, doing that (sometimes). For me, it's been helpful to acknowledge that although I may feel like an imposter, it doesn't mean that I am one. I try to separate the feelings from the facts. If I feel like I don't belong in the room then I think more deeply about why I believe that. If it's because of a lack of skills, I try to do the work to gain those qualifications. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I've also learned to talk to myself in a way that I would talk to a friend who is going through the same situation as me. Often, we talk to ourselves in a way that we wouldn't tolerate from anyone else. Be kind to yourself and work on creating a healthy mental dialogue about any mistakes you make. Mistakes are normal, and what's important is that we learn from them and grow. You got this, friend!</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Q: "I've often heard that people don't quit jobs, they quit managers. How often do you believe this to be true?"—Ben in Florida </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>A: </strong>Everyone's reasons for leaving a job are unique, but I do think it happens often enough. When I conduct exit interviews or speak to people in my professional/personal circle, the way their manager treats them is almost always mentioned. Leaving a role because of a manager has to be a top 5 reason, and it's not No. 5.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Q: "How do you know when it’s time to leave a job? There’s not much more room to grow and raises will become smaller over time because I’m not allowed to be paid at another occupational level."—Sal</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>A: </strong>*Stares at answer in question*</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Something bothering you at work? </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23486973.16825/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77C474a70d2?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" data-saferedirecturl="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23486973.16825/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77C474a70d2?utm_source%3Dmorning_brew&source=gmail&ust=1619903215869000&usg=AFQjCNFBtZApbMVGjXlYX7b_MLoGThyNfA" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Ask Kate for advice here</em></a><em>.</em></p>

<td align="left" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 10px 0px; word-break: break-word;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #ffe62e 25%, #0f9046); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
The Debate Over Political Debate at Work
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/30/basecamp-joins-coinbase-banning-social-political-talk-work" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Laptop with political stickers on it " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNTc0L3dvcmtwbGFjZV9wb2xpdGljcy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Will Varner</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The leaders of Chicago-based software company Basecamp don't always follow the playbook. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Basecamp has <a href="https://www.bizjournals.com/chicago/inno/stories/inno-insights/2019/04/23/bootstrapping-in-chicago.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">shunned</a> raising money from venture capitalists, typically a rite of passage for most tech firms. CEO Jason Fried and cofounder David Heinemeier Hansson, wrote a book called <em>Remote:</em> <em>Office Not Required</em>...in 2013. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But very few expected when, on Monday, Fried <a href="https://world.hey.com/jason/changes-at-basecamp-7f32afc5?utm_source=st&utm_medium=en&utm_campaign=inno&ana=e_n" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">posted a blog</a> on the company website in which he banned "societal and political discussions" from Basecamp's internal chats. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Fried's thinking? </p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>"Sensitivities are at 11, and every discussion remotely related to politics, advocacy, or society at large quickly spins away from pleasant."</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>"It's become too much. It's a major distraction. It saps our energy and redirects our dialog towards dark places. It's not healthy, it hasn't served us well. And we're done with it on our company Basecamp account where the work happens."</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">Ahead of the times...or self-defeating? </h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Basecamp's directive to ban political debate internally drew loads of criticism from both inside and outside the company. Some tech leaders, like Facebook cofounder and current Asana CEO Dustin Moskovitz, said instead of pushing uncomfortable issues to the sidelines, companies <a href="https://twitter.com/moskov/status/1386826921850269703?s=20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">should</a> "actively create spaces for these conversations."</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Some employees at Basecamp itself, according to the journalist Casey Newton, who interviewed about a half dozen of them, said the new policy was apparently <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/4/27/22406673/basecamp-political-speech-policy-controversy?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">made in response</a> to a diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) push from some workers at the company. Hansson told Newton he found those conversations to be distracting from Basecamp's primary goal of making good products.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So it wasn't really about arguments over Trump or immigration or climate change (you can find Fried and Hansson regularly championing progressive causes online), but instead about Basecamp's response to employees' DEI efforts in its own workplace. </p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">Will more companies follow? </h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Before Basecamp banned political debate, there was Coinbase. Last September, the crypto exchange's CEO Brian Armstrong <a href="https://blog.coinbase.com/coinbase-is-a-mission-focused-company-af882df8804?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pioneered</a> the "no political talk at work" trend to ensure the company remained focused on its business mission. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">You can imagine the conversations on Election Day…</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">  <img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80OTI1L3R5bGVyX2RlbmtfdHdlZXRfYWJvdXRfY29pbmJhc2UucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIn0=" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 458px;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Tyler Denk on Twitter</em> </small></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">After Fried announced Basecamp's new policy, Armstrong <a href="https://twitter.com/brian_armstrong/status/1386806511628783617?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tweeted</a>: "Another mission focused company <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/clapping-hands-sign_1f44f.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> it takes courage in these times."</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Zoom out: </strong>While they haven't gone as far as Coinbase or Basecamp, other tech companies have put up guardrails around what employees can or cannot talk about in internal chats.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1">
<span>In 2019, Google </span><span><a href="https://www.vox.com/recode/2019/8/23/20829430/google-new-community-guidelines-employees-political-speech-internal-debate?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">discouraged</a></span><span> employees from talking politics in company forums.</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1">
<span>Last September, Facebook rolled out </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-17/facebook-to-moderate-employee-discussions-about-social-issues?sref=KkPzpZvz" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new guidelines</a></span><span> that moderated political speech on its internal messaging service.</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Pinterest took down a Slack channel that was used to question leadership around bias and pay equity, the Washington Post reported. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Bottom line: </strong>Tech investor Paul Graham said he <a href="https://twitter.com/paulg/status/1310583298666696705?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">predicts</a> "most successful companies will follow Coinbase's lead" or else get lapped by those who do. But when corporate execs are increasingly speaking out around issues such as voting rights and racial injustice, they may find it more difficult to stop employees from doing the same. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">About one-third of Basecamp’s ~60 employees reportedly accepted buyouts on Friday.</p>

Open House: Kentucky Derby Edition
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Happy Sunday and welcome to Open House, where we can all be a little judgmental of a fancy bathroom even if ours hasn't been cleaned in a while. We'll give you a few facts about a home listing, and you try to guess the price.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/7AEDJ3ayIbisihF8Dm/giphy.gif" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Zillow</em> </small></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Come on down to Louisville, KY, home of yesterday's Kentucky Derby and potentially you if this 9,071 square-foot house is your style. This beautiful <a href="https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/5803-Orion-Rd-Louisville-KY-40222/2128937001_zpid/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">three-story home</a> was built in 1908 and is situated in the historic Glenview neighborhood, seven miles from downtown. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>6 beds, 6 baths</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>A 2.7-acre lot with a log cabin guest house that was built in 1840</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>All the vintage wallpaper your heart desires</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Your own little secret garden that leads to an in-ground pool</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much to be near the Churchill Downs action? Make your guess, then scroll down to find the answer.</p>

<li aria-level="1">
<span>The US fugitive who stole a Canadian hotel. </li>
<li aria-level="1">
<span>How five college friends invested in a racehorse that made it to the Kentucky Derby. (</span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/30/hot-rod-charlie-five-best-human-friends-big-kentucky-derby-dreams?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Morning Brew</a></span><span>)</span>

#353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eApollo 11 astronaut Michael Collins, the third crew member on the first mission to the moon, died this week at 90. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eUnlike Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin, Collins never walked on the lunar surface, and instead piloted the command module around the moon while Armstrong and Aldrin snagged the headlines. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAs Collins passed the dark side of the moon, his communications with Earth were completely severed, making him possibly the most isolated person ever to live. “If a count were taken, the score would be three billion plus two over on the other side of the moon, and one plus God only knows what on this side,” he wrote.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut Collins, like many of us this past year, somehow managed to find comfort in that loneliness. “I had this beautiful little domain,” he said. “I was the emperor, the captain of it, and it was quite commodious. I had warm coffee, even.” Sometimes it’s the little things.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; Andrew Ross Sorkin\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Andrew Ross Sorkin\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80OTE0L2FuZHJld19yb3NzX3Nvcmtpbi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eThos Robinson/Getty Images for New York Times\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eJournalist Andrew Ross Sorkin co-anchors CNBC's \u003cem\u003eSquawk Box\u003c/em\u003e, founded the OG business newsletter DealBook, interviewed Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev the night of the GameStop fiasco, wrote \u003cem\u003eToo Big to Fail, \u003c/em\u003eco-created \u003cem\u003eBillions\u003c/em\u003e, says \"\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/andrewrsorkin/status/1384148090005848072?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egood morning\u003c/a\u003e\" to everyone on his morning runs through Central Park...is there anything the man can't do? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe asked him some icebreaker questions to find out. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat activities, realizations, or new ways of doing things will you (try to) keep from this past year?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt's probably a cliche, but the pandemic created a lot of clarity for me about better balancing work with family. I work 80+ hours a week and I've always done it because I love it. (I don't feel like I've worked a day in my life, for real.) But being at an office and traveling all the time is different than working next to my sons or daughter at home. So I'm going to try to figure out how to do a lot more of my work with my family within reach and to be more strategic about travel, work dinners, etc. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou can only do one: writing for the New York Times, TV anchoring, or producing (co-creating \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eBillions\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e for Showtime, developing a GameStop film for HBO).\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eDon't hate me for this answer: I genuinely love all three. It is kinda like asking which of my three children I would be willing to give up! None of them!\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMost intimidating exec to interview?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe first time I did a long-form interview with Bill Gates, maybe a decade ago, I was practically sweating. It isn't that he is intimidating as a person; it is that he is so smart and deep on so many different topics. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat's the best part about waking up at 4:30am? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHonestly? That hour is tough. But I do jump out of bed excited about the opportunity to have breakfast—on television, no less—with some of the biggest newsmakers in the world, often in the middle of the most interesting moments of their lives. And there is very little traffic then. :)\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you could devote a year to researching someone's biography, who would your subject be?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLiving or dead? Satoshi Nakamoto. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is the dumbest thing you made your parents buy for you as a kid?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI was a baseball and basketball card junkie and a wannabe entrepreneur. I convinced my father, based on my track record of making money trading cards, to invest in a case of Fleer Ultra baseball cards. I told him we'd double our money. Of course, the cards are now worthless—less than worthless. We still have the cards if anyone wants to buy them.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat would you write on a gigantic billboard?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\"Breathe. Things are never as good or as bad as they seem.\"\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F04%2F30%2Ficebreakers-withandrew-ross-sorkin\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make It Work logo\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEach week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers \u003ca href=\"https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereader-submitted questions\u003c/a\u003e about work in 2021. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: \"Hi, Kate. I'm 24 years old and a few years into my career as a software engineer. I've suffered from impostor syndrome since I was a freshman in college. Any advice on overcoming this?\"—Justin in Colorado \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA: \u003c/strong\u003eImposter syndrome makes things seem too good to be true, huh? Been there, doing that (sometimes). For me, it's been helpful to acknowledge that although I may feel like an imposter, it doesn't mean that I am one. I try to separate the feelings from the facts. If I feel like I don't belong in the room then I think more deeply about why I believe that. If it's because of a lack of skills, I try to do the work to gain those qualifications. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI've also learned to talk to myself in a way that I would talk to a friend who is going through the same situation as me. Often, we talk to ourselves in a way that we wouldn't tolerate from anyone else. Be kind to yourself and work on creating a healthy mental dialogue about any mistakes you make. Mistakes are normal, and what's important is that we learn from them and grow. You got this, friend!\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: \"I've often heard that people don't quit jobs, they quit managers. How often do you believe this to be true?\"—Ben in Florida \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA: \u003c/strong\u003eEveryone's reasons for leaving a job are unique, but I do think it happens often enough. When I conduct exit interviews or speak to people in my professional/personal circle, the way their manager treats them is almost always mentioned. Leaving a role because of a manager has to be a top 5 reason, and it's not No. 5.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: \"How do you know when it’s time to leave a job? There’s not much more room to grow and raises will become smaller over time because I’m not allowed to be paid at another occupational level.\"—Sal\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA: \u003c/strong\u003e*Stares at answer in question*\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nThe Debate Over Political Debate at Work\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/30/basecamp-joins-coinbase-banning-social-political-talk-work\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Laptop with political stickers on it \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNTc0L3dvcmtwbGFjZV9wb2xpdGljcy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eWill Varner\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe leaders of Chicago-based software company Basecamp don't always follow the playbook. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBasecamp has \u003ca href=\"https://www.bizjournals.com/chicago/inno/stories/inno-insights/2019/04/23/bootstrapping-in-chicago.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eshunned\u003c/a\u003e raising money from venture capitalists, typically a rite of passage for most tech firms. CEO Jason Fried and cofounder David Heinemeier Hansson, wrote a book called \u003cem\u003eRemote:\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003eOffice Not Required\u003c/em\u003e...in 2013. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut very few expected when, on Monday, Fried \u003ca href=\"https://world.hey.com/jason/changes-at-basecamp-7f32afc5?utm_source=st\u0026utm_medium=en\u0026utm_campaign=inno\u0026ana=e_n\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eposted a blog\u003c/a\u003e on the company website in which he banned \"societal and political discussions\" from Basecamp's internal chats. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eFried's thinking? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\"Sensitivities are at 11, and every discussion remotely related to politics, advocacy, or society at large quickly spins away from pleasant.\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\"It's become too much. It's a major distraction. It saps our energy and redirects our dialog towards dark places. It's not healthy, it hasn't served us well. And we're done with it on our company Basecamp account where the work happens.\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eAhead of the times...or self-defeating? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBasecamp's directive to ban political debate internally drew loads of criticism from both inside and outside the company. Some tech leaders, like Facebook cofounder and current Asana CEO Dustin Moskovitz, said instead of pushing uncomfortable issues to the sidelines, companies \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/moskov/status/1386826921850269703?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eshould\u003c/a\u003e \"actively create spaces for these conversations.\"\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSome employees at Basecamp itself, according to the journalist Casey Newton, who interviewed about a half dozen of them, said the new policy was apparently \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2021/4/27/22406673/basecamp-political-speech-policy-controversy?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emade in response\u003c/a\u003e to a diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) push from some workers at the company. Hansson told Newton he found those conversations to be distracting from Basecamp's primary goal of making good products.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo it wasn't really about arguments over Trump or immigration or climate change (you can find Fried and Hansson regularly championing progressive causes online), but instead about Basecamp's response to employees' DEI efforts in its own workplace. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eWill more companies follow? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBefore Basecamp banned political debate, there was Coinbase. Last September, the crypto exchange's CEO Brian Armstrong \u003ca href=\"https://blog.coinbase.com/coinbase-is-a-mission-focused-company-af882df8804?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epioneered\u003c/a\u003e the \"no political talk at work\" trend to ensure the company remained focused on its business mission. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYou can imagine the conversations on Election Day…\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e  \u003cimg src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80OTI1L3R5bGVyX2RlbmtfdHdlZXRfYWJvdXRfY29pbmJhc2UucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIn0=\" class=\"img-responsive\" width=\"640\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 458px;\" alt=\"\" data-reactroot=\"\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e \u003cem\u003eTyler Denk on Twitter\u003c/em\u003e \u003c/small\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAfter Fried announced Basecamp's new policy, Armstrong \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/brian_armstrong/status/1386806511628783617?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etweeted\u003c/a\u003e: \"Another mission focused company \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/clapping-hands-sign_1f44f.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e it takes courage in these times.\"\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile they haven't gone as far as Coinbase or Basecamp, other tech companies have put up guardrails around what employees can or cannot talk about in internal chats.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIn 2019, Google \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.vox.com/recode/2019/8/23/20829430/google-new-community-guidelines-employees-political-speech-internal-debate?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ediscouraged\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e employees from talking politics in company forums.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eLast September, Facebook rolled out \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-17/facebook-to-moderate-employee-discussions-about-social-issues?sref=KkPzpZvz\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew guidelines\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e that moderated political speech on its internal messaging service.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePinterest took down a Slack channel that was used to question leadership around bias and pay equity, the Washington Post reported. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eTech investor Paul Graham said he \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/paulg/status/1310583298666696705?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epredicts\u003c/a\u003e \"most successful companies will follow Coinbase's lead\" or else get lapped by those who do.
